	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	doing, and partly to get comfort from you for my suffering.
	For I have taken in the maiden—but I think she is no
	maiden, but taken by him—as a captain takes on a cargo, a
	merchandise that does outrage to my feelings. And now
	the two of us remain beneath one blanket for him to
	embrace; such is the reward that Heracles, he who is called
	true and noble, has sent me for having kept the house so
	long. I do not know how to be angry with my husband now
	that he is suffering severely from this malady; yet what
	woman could live together with this girl, sharing a marriage
	with the same man? For I see her youth advancing,
	and mine perishing; and the desiring eye turns away from
	those whose bloom it snatches. This is why I am afraid that
	Heracles may be called my husband, but the younger
	woman’s man. But as I said it is not honourable for a
	woman of sense to be angry; and I shall tell you what
	means I have of remedying pain.I had an ancient gift from a monster long ago, hidden in
	a brazen pot, a thing I received as a girl from the blood of
	Nessus of the shaggy chest at his death, him who for a fee
	used to carry people across the broad flow of the river
	Evenus, not by plying oars to transport them nor by a ship
	with sails, but in his arms. While he was carrying me upon

	gave me, his side pained by the cruel arrow’s point, but
	observed them, like writing hard to wash away from a
	bronze tablet. \[These were his orders, and these I carried
	out.\] I was to keep in a secret place the unguent, far from
	the fire and never warmed by the sun’s ray, until I should
	apply it, newly rubbed, on something; and that is what I
	did. Now, when it was time to act, I rubbed it in secret, in a
	room inside the house, with a fleece of wool, a tuft pulled
	from a sheep belonging to our flock, folded it, and placed
	the gift, which the sun had never touched, in a container,
	as you saw.And when I was going out I saw a thing too strange for
	words, beyond human understanding. I happened to have
	thrown the piece of sheep’s wool \[with which I had rubbed

	and when it grew warm, it melted away into nothing and
	crumbled on the ground, looking most like the sawdust

	had fallen; and from the ground where it was lying clotted
	foam boiled up, as when the rich liquid from the blue-green
	fruit is poured upon the ground from the vine of
	Bacchus.So I do not know, in my trouble, what decision to come

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	to; and I see that I have done a terrible thing. For why, in
	return for what, could the monster have done a kindness to
	me, the cause of his death? It cannot be; but he cajoled me,
	wishing to destroy the man who had shot him; this I learn
	too late, when the knowledge cannot serve me. For if I am
	not to prove mistaken in my judgment, I alone, miserable
	one, shall be his ruin; I know that the arrow that struck him
	tormented even Chiron, who was immortal, and it destroys
	all the beasts whom it touches. How shall the black poison
	of the blood, coming from the fatal wound, not destroy my
	husband also? That is my belief. Well, I have determined,
	if he comes to grief, that with the same movement I too
	shall die with him. For a woman whose care is to be good
	cannot bear to live and to enjoy evil repute.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Dreadful actions must needs inspire fear; but one should
	not expect the worst before the thing has happened.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	When one has proved ill-advised, there is no hope that can
	furnish any confidence.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	But when people come to grief through no fault of their
	own, anger is softened, and you should benefit from this.

	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Deianeira[/b][/c]
	What have you said, my son? On whose warrant do you say
	that I have done a deed so much to be deplored?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	I saw with my own eyes my father’s dire calamity; I did not
	hear tell of it.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Deianeira[/b][/c]
	Where did you approach him and stand by?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	If you must hear the story, I must tell you all. When he returned
	from sacking the city of Eurytus, bringing the trophies
	of victory and the first fruits—there is a sea-swept
	cape in Euboea, Mount Cenaeum, where he was marking
	off altars and a sacred grove for Zeus his father. That is
	where I first saw him, much relieved, for I had missed him.
	And as he was about to slaughter the many beasts for sacrifice,
	there came from home his own herald, Lichas, bringing
	your gift, the robe of death. He put it on, as you had instructed,
	and slew twelve bulls without a blemish, as the
	first fruits of the spoils; but in all he was bringing up a hundred
	cattle of all kinds. At first, poor man, he spoke the
	prayer cheerfully, rejoicing in the fine attire. But when the
	bloodshot flame from the sacred offerings and from the
	resinous pine blazed up, the sweat came up upon his body,

	called me, saying, “Boy, come here, do not run away from
	my trouble, not even if you have to share my death! Lift me
	and take me out of this, and, if you can, place me where no
	man can look upon me! But if you pity me, transport me at
	least out of this country; let me not die here!” When he had
	given this command, we put him right into a boat, and with
	much trouble brought him to this land, bellowing as the
	spasms seized him. In a moment you will see him, either
	alive or lately dead.These are the plot and the action, mother, of which you
	are convicted, for which may avenging Justice and the
	Erinys punish you! And if right permits it, I utter a curse on
	you! And right does permit it, since you have made it right
	for me, killing the noblest man upon the earth, one such as
	you shall never see again!

	τοσαῦτα φωνήσασα συντόνῳ χερὶ
	λύει τὸν αὑτῆς πέπλον, οὗ χρυσήλατος
	[c dimgray]925[/c]προὔκειτο μαστῶν περονίς, ἐκ δ᾿ ἐλώπισεν

	κἀν ᾧ τὸ κεῖσε δεῦρό τ᾿ ἐξορμώμεθα,
	[c dimgray]930[/c]ὁρῶμεν αὐτὴν ἀμφιπλῆγι φασγάνῳ
	πλευρὰν ὑφ᾿ ἧπαρ καὶ φρένας πεπληγμένην.
	ἰδὼν δ᾿ ὁ παῖς ᾤμωξεν· ἔγνω γὰρ τάλας
	τοὔργον κατ᾿ ὀργὴν ὡς ἐφάψειεν τόδε,
	ὄψ᾿ ἐκδιδαχθεὶς τῶν κατ᾿ οἶκον οὕνεκα
	[c dimgray]935[/c]ἄκουσα πρὸς τοῦ θηρὸς ἔρξειεν τάδε.
	κἀνταῦθ᾿ ὁ παῖς δύστηνος οὔτ᾿ ὀδυρμάτων
	ἐλείπετ᾿ οὐδέν, ἀμφί νιν γοώμενος,
	οὔτ᾿ ἀμφιπίπτων στόμασιν, ἀλλὰ πλευρόθεν
	πλευρὰν παρεὶς ἔκειτο πόλλ᾿ ἀναστένων,
	[c dimgray]940[/c]ὥς νιν ματαίως αἰτίᾳ βάλοι κακῇ,
	κλαίων ὁθούνεχ᾿ εἷς δυοῖν ἔσοιθ᾿ ἅμα,
	πατρός τ᾿ ἐκείνης τ᾿, ὠρφανισμένος βίον.
	τοιαῦτα τἀνθάδ᾿ ἐστίν. ὥστ᾿ εἴ τις δύο
	ἢ κἀπὶ πλείους ἡμέρας λογίζεται,
	[c dimgray]945[/c]μάταιός ἐστιν· οὐ γὰρ ἔσθ᾿ ἥ γ᾿ αὔριον
	πρὶν εὖ πάθῃ τις τὴν παροῦσαν ἡμέραν.

	bridal bed, farewell now for ever, since you will never again
	receive me to lie upon this couch.” Having said so much,
	with a sweeping hand she loosed her robe, where a gold
	pin lay above her breasts, and bared all her side and her left
	arm. And I ran with all my strength, and warned her son of
	what she was about. And in the time in which I was running
	there and back, we saw that she had struck herself with a
	two-edged sword in the side below the liver and the seat of
	life. When he saw, her son cried out; for he realised, poor
	man, that he had charged her with the crime in anger, having
	learned too late from those in the house that that monster
	had got her to do this act in innocence.Then her unhappy son never ceased to lament, weeping
	over her, nor to cover her with kisses, but lying side by
	side with her he uttered many a groan, saying that he had
	charged her falsely with the crime, and weeping because
	now he would be bereft of both, his father and her also.
	That is how things stand here; so that if anyone reckons on
	two days or more, he is acting foolishly, for there is no tomorrow
	till one has got through today in happiness.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]Exit nurse[/c].

	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Which case shall I lament for first? Which is the sadder? It
	is hard for me, poor creature, to decide.The one we can see in the house, the other we await in
	expectation; seeing and waiting to see are just the same.I wish a breath of wind would come to the house to waft
	me from this place, to save me from dying at once with fear
	at the mere sight of the mighty son of Zeus; for they say
	that he is approaching before the house in agony that cannot
	be got rid of, a sight unspeakable.So when I lamented like the shrill-voiced nightingale, it
	was for what was near, not what was far! For here is a party
	of strangers, come from far away. Where, now, are they
	carrying him? As though caring for one dear to them they
	are planting silently their heavy tread. Alas, he is speechless
	as he is borne along. Must I judge him to be dead, or
	sleeping?
	[m1]\ [/m]

	doctor.

	δεινῆς Ἐχίδνης θρέμμα, τόν τε χρυσέων
	[c dimgray]1100[/c]δράκοντα μήλων φύλακ᾿ ἐπ᾿ ἐσχάτοις τόποις.
	ἄλλων τε μόχθων μυρίων ἐγευσάμην,
	κοὐδεὶς τροπαῖ᾿ ἔστησε τῶν ἐμῶν χερῶν.
	νῦν δ᾿ ὧδ᾿ ἄναρθρος καὶ κατερρακωμένος
	τυφλῆς ὑπ᾿ ἄτης ἐκπεπόρθημαι τάλας,
	[c dimgray]1105[/c]ὁ τῆς ἀρίστης μητρὸς ὠνομασμένος,
	ὁ τοῦ κατ᾿ ἄστρα Ζηνὸς αὐδηθεὶς γόνος.
	ἀλλ᾿ εὖ γέ τοι τόδ᾿ ἴστε, κἂν τὸ μηδὲν ὦ,
	κἂν μηδὲν ἕρπω, τήν γε δράσασαν τάδε
	χειρώσομαι κἀκ τῶνδε. προσμόλοι μόνον,
	[c dimgray]1110[/c]ἵν᾿ ἐκδιδαχθῇ πᾶσιν ἀγγέλλειν ὅτι
	καὶ ζῶν κακούς γε καὶ θανὼν ἐτεισάμην.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ὦ τλῆμον Ἑλλάς, πένθος οἷον εἰσορῶ <σ᾿>
	ἕξουσαν, ἀνδρὸς τοῦδέ γ᾿ εἰ σφαλεῖσ᾿ ἔσῃ.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1112[/sup][/c]suppl. Ll.-J.<li id="note_LCL021_230_1113" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1113[/sup][/c]σφαλεῖσ᾿ ἔσῃ Meineke: σφαλήσεται codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 230[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	strike me! Hurl down your thunderbolt, lord, cast it upon
	me, father! For again it is feasting on me, it has blossomed,
	it is launched! O hands, hands, O back and shoulders, O
	dear arms, are you they that once by force subdued the
	dweller in Nemea, the scourge of herdsmen, the lion, a
	creature none could approach and none confront, and the
	Lernaean Hydra, and the fierce army of the monsters, with
	two natures and with horses’ feet, insolent, lawless, overwhelming
	in their might,
	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c] and the beast of Erymanthus,
	and the three-headed dog of Hades below the earth, a portent
	irresistible, the nursling of dread Echidna, and the
	serpent that guarded the golden apples in its place remote?
	And I sampled many thousand other labours, and
	none yet has raised a trophy for victory against my might!
	But now with joints unhinged and torn to rags I ammiserably
	conquered by blind ruin, I, called the child of the noblest
	of mothers, I, saluted as the son of Zeus among the
	stars! But know this for certain, even if I amount to nothing
	and I cannot move, I shall chastise her who has done this,
	even in this condition! Let her only come near, so that she
	may be taught to proclaim to all that both in life and death I
	have punished evildoers!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Unhappy Greece, what mourning I see will be yours, if you
	are deprived of this man!
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c]The Centaurs.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 231[/c]

-021.233 (SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis)
%Sophocles The Women of Trachis
SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ἐπεὶ παρέσχες ἀντιφωνῆσαι, πάτερ,
	[c dimgray]1115[/c]σιγὴν παρασχὼν κλῦθί μου νοσῶν ὅμως.
	αἰτήσομαι γάρ σ᾿ ὧν δίκαια τυγχάνειν.
	δός μοι σεαυτόν, μὴ τοιοῦτον ὡς δάκνῃ
	θυμῷ δύσοργος. οὐ γὰρ ἂν γνοίης ἐν οἷς
	χαίρειν προθυμῇ κἀν ὅτοις ἀλγεῖς μάτην.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1120[/c]εἰπὼν ὃ χρῄζεις λῆξον· ὡς ἐγὼ νοσῶν
	οὐδὲν ξυνίημ᾿ ὧν σὺ ποικίλλεις πάλαι.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	τῆς μητρὸς ἥκω τῆς ἐμῆς φράσων ἐν οἷς
	νῦν ἔστ᾿ ἐν οἷς θ᾿ ἥμαρτεν οὐχ ἑκουσία.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ὦ παγκάκιστε, καὶ παρεμνήσω γὰρ αὖ
	[c dimgray]1125[/c]τῆς πατροφόντου μητρός, ὡς κλύειν ἐμέ;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ἔχει γὰρ οὕτως ὥστε μὴ σιγᾶν πρέπειν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	οὐ δῆτα τοῖς γε πρόσθεν ἡμαρτημένοις.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ἀλλ᾿ οὐδὲ μὲν δὴ τοῖς γ᾿ ἐφ᾿ ἡμέραν ἐρεῖς.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1117[/sup][/c]τοιοῦτον Mudge: τοσοῦτον codd.<li id="note_LCL021_232_1123" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1123[/sup][/c]ἔστ᾿ ἐν Harleianus 5743 (coni. Blaydes): ἐστιν cett.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 232[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Since you have given me leave to answer you, father, be silent
	and hear me, sick though you are, for I shall make a request
	which in justice should be granted. Lend yourself to
	me, not in such a mood that you are out of temper and are
	stung to anger; else you could not learn how mistaken is
	your desire for satisfaction and how mistaken your resentment.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Say what you wish and then leave off! For I am sick, and
	understand none of the subtleties you have long been talking.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	I have come to tell you about my mother, how it now stands
	with her and how she did wrong by accident.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	You utter villain, have you again made mention of the
	mother who has killed your father, in my hearing?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Yes, for things stand so with her that silence would be
	wrong.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Indeed no, when you think of the wrong she did before!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Not when you consider what she has done this day as well!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 233[/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Speak, but take care that you are not revealed to be a traitor!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	I will speak; she is dead, newly slain!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	At whose hand? A miracle, told by a prophet who speaks
	evil!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	By her own hand, not that of any other.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Ah me! Before she could die at my hand, as she should
	have done?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]

	φανῶ δ᾿ ἐγὼ τούτοισι συμβαίνοντ᾿ ἴσα
	[m1]\ [/m]

	the whole brood of your siblings, and summon the unhappy

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	But your mother is not here; she has come to terms with
	Tiryns by the shore so as to reside there; some of your children

	[m1]\ [/m]

	where you will show what sort of a man you are, you that

	living, but at that of one who was dead and lived in Hades.
	So this monster the Centaur, as the divine prophecy had
	foretold, has killed me, I being alive and he dead. And I
	shall reveal new prophecies that fit with these, saying the
	[m1]\ [/m]

	same as the prophecies of old, that when I entered the

	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c] who live in the mountains and sleep

	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1185[/c]ὄμνυ Διός νυν τοῦ με φύσαντος κάρα.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ἦ μὴν τί δράσειν; καὶ τόδ᾿ ἐξειπεῖν σε δεῖ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἦ μὴν ἐμοὶ τὸ λεχθὲν ἔργον ἐκτελεῖν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ὄμνυμ᾿ ἔγωγε, Ζῆν᾿ ἔχων ἐπώμοτον.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	εἰ δ᾿ ἐκτὸς ἔλθοις, πημονὰς εὔχου λαβεῖν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1190[/c]οὐ μὴ λάβω· δράσω γάρ· εὔχομαι δ᾿ ὅμως.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	οἶσθ᾿ οὖν τὸν Οἴτης Ζηνὸς ὑψίστου πάγον;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	οἶδ᾿, ὡς θυτήρ γε πολλὰ δὴ σταθεὶς ἄνω.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἐνταῦθά νυν χρὴ τοὐμὸν ἐξάραντά σε
	σῶμ᾿ αὐτόχειρα καὶ ξὺν οἷς χρῄζεις φίλων,
	[c dimgray]1195[/c]πολλὴν μὲν ὕλην τῆς βαθυρρίζου δρυὸς
	κείραντα, πολλὸν δ᾿ ἄρσεν᾿ ἐκτεμόνθ᾿ ὁμοῦ
	ἄγριον ἔλαιον, σῶμα τοὐμὸν ἐμβαλεῖν,
	καὶ πευκίνης λαβόντα λαμπάδος σέλας
	πρῆσαι. γόου δὲ μηδὲν εἰσίδω δάκρυ,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1186[/sup][/c]ἐξειπεῖν σε δεῖ Heimsoeth: ἐξειρήσεται codd.<li id="note_LCL021_240_1191" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1191[/sup][/c]ὑψίστου Wakefield: ὕψιστον codd.<li id="note_LCL021_240_1199" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1199[/sup][/c]εἰσίδω Jackson: εἰσίτω codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 240[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Now swear by the head of Zeus who was my father!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	What must I swear to do? You must tell me that also!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	You must swear to perform the action that I speak of!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	I swear, calling Zeus to witness!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Pray, too, that you may incur penalties if you depart from
	this!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	I shall not incur them, for I shall do it; but none the less I
	pray for this!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Then do you know the mountain of Oeta, which belongs to
	highest Zeus?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	I know it, having often stood up there to sacrifice.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	You must lift my body and carry it there with your own
	hands and with those of your friends you choose. When
	you have cut down much timber from the deeply rooted
	trees and many branches of the tough wild olive, throw my
	body onto the wood; then take a burning torch of pine-wood
	and set fire to it. And let me see no tear of lamentation,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 241[/c]

-021.243 (SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis)
%Sophocles The Women of Trachis
SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	[c dimgray]1200[/c]ἀλλ᾿ ἀστένακτος κἀδάκρυτος, εἴπερ εἶ
	τοῦδ᾿ ἀνδρός, ἔρξον· εἰ δὲ μή, μενῶ σ᾿ ἐγὼ
	καὶ νέρθεν ὢν ἀραῖος εἰσαεὶ βαρύς.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	οἴμοι, πάτερ, τί εἶπας; οἷά μ᾿ εἴργασαι.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ὁποῖα δραστέ᾿ ἐστίν· εἰ δὲ μή, πατρὸς
	[c dimgray]1205[/c]ἄλλου γενοῦ του μηδ᾿ ἐμὸς κληθῇς ἔτι.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	οἴμοι μάλ᾿ αὖθις, οἷά μ᾿ ἐκκαλῇ, πάτερ,
	φονέα γενέσθαι καὶ παλαμναῖον σέθεν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	οὐ δῆτ᾿ ἔγωγ᾿, ἀλλ᾿ ὧν ἔχω παιώνιον
	καὶ μοῦνον ἰατῆρα τῶν ἐμῶν κακῶν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1210[/c]καὶ πῶς ὑπαίθων σῶμ᾿ ἂν ἰῴμην τὸ σόν;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἀλλ᾿ εἰ φοβῇ πρὸς τοῦτο, τἄλλα γ᾿ ἔργασαι.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	φορᾶς γέ τοι φθόνησις οὐ γενήσεται.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἦ καὶ πυρᾶς πλήρωμα τῆς εἰρημένης;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ὅσον γ᾿ ἂν αὐτὸς μὴ ποτιψαύων χεροῖν·
	[c dimgray]1215[/c]τὰ δ᾿ ἄλλα πράξω κοὐ καμῇ τοὐμὸν μέρος.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 242[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	but do the work without mourning and without weeping,
	if you are this man’s son! If you do not, I shall remain as
	a grievous curse upon you even below the earth!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Alas, father, what have you said? What are you doing to
	me?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	What must be done! And if not, become the son of some
	other father and be called mine no more!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Alas once more, what a demand you are making of me, father,
	to have the guilt of your murder on my hands!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Not I, but to be the healer and the only curer of the ills
	from which I suffer!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	And how could I heal your body by setting light to it?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Well, if you are afraid of that, do at least the rest!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	I shall not grudge the act of carrying you there.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	And also that of piling up the pyre?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Except that I shall not put my own hands to it.
	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c] But the rest
	I shall do and I shall not fail you.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c]The usual story was that the pyre was lit by Philoctetes.
	[m1]\ [/m]

-021.245 (SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis)
%Sophocles The Women of Trachis
SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἀλλ᾿ ἀρκέσει καὶ ταῦτα· πρόσνειμαι δέ μοι
	χάριν βραχεῖαν πρὸς μακροῖς ἄλλοις διδούς.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	εἰ καὶ μακρὰ κάρτ᾿ ἐστίν, ἐργασθήσεται.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	τὴν Εὐρυτείαν οἶσθα δῆτα παρθένον;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1220[/c]Ἰόλην ἔλεξας, ὥς γ᾿ ἐπεικάζειν ἐμέ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἔγνως. τοσοῦτον δή σ᾿ ἐπισκήπτω, τέκνον·
	ταύτην, ἐμοῦ θανόντος, εἴπερ εὐσεβεῖν
	βούλῃ, πατρῴων ὁρκίων μεμνημένος,
	προσθοῦ δάμαρτα, μηδ᾿ ἀπιστήσῃς πατρί·
	[c dimgray]1225[/c]μηδ᾿ ἄλλος ἀνδρῶν τοῖς ἐμοῖς πλευροῖς ὁμοῦ
	κλιθεῖσαν αὐτὴν ἀντὶ σοῦ λάβῃ ποτέ,
	ἀλλ᾿ αὐτός, ὦ παῖ, τοῦτο κήδευσον λέχος.
	πείθου· τὸ γάρ τοι μεγάλα πιστεύσαντ᾿ ἐμοὶ
	σμικροῖς ἀπιστεῖν τὴν πάρος συγχεῖ χάριν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1230[/c]οἴμοι. τὸ μὲν νοσοῦντι θυμοῦσθαι κακόν,
	τὸ δ᾿ ὧδ᾿ ὁρᾶν φρονοῦντα τίς ποτ᾿ ἂν φέροι;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ὡς ἐργασείων οὐδὲν ὧν λέγω θροεῖς.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1220[/sup][/c]ὥς γ᾿ Schaefer: ὥστ᾿ codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 244[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	That much will suffice; but grant me in addition a small favour,
	over and above great things!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Even if it is a great one, it shall surely be done.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	You know, surely, the daughter of Eurytus?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	You mean Iole, as I guess.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	You are right! This is the charge I lay on you, my son: when
	I am dead, if you wish to show loyalty, remembering the
	oath you swore your father, make her your wife, and do not
	disobey me; and let no other man but you take her, who has
	lain by my side, but make this marriage yourself! Obey, for
	to fail me in small things when you have complied with me
	in great ones annihilates your earlier kindness.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Alas! To be angry with a sick man is wrong; but who could
	bear to see you thinking as you are?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	You speak as though you intend to do none of the things I
	ask.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 245[/c]

-021.247 (SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis)
%Sophocles The Women of Trachis
SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	τίς γάρ ποθ᾿, ἥ μοι μητρὶ μὲν θανεῖν μόνη
	μεταίτιος, σοὶ δ᾿ αὖθις ὡς ἔχεις ἔχειν,
	[c dimgray]1235[/c]τίς ταῦτ᾿ ἄν, ὅστις μὴ ᾿ξ ἀλαστόρων νοσοῖ,
	ἕλοιτο; κρεῖσσον κἀμέ γ᾿, ὦ πάτερ, θανεῖν
	ἢ τοῖσιν ἐχθίστοισι συνναίειν ὁμοῦ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἁνὴρ ὅδ᾿ ὡς ἔοικεν οὐ νεμεῖν ἐμοὶ
	φθίνοντι μοῖραν· ἀλλά τοι θεῶν ἀρὰ
	[c dimgray]1240[/c]μενεῖ σ᾿ ἀπιστήσαντα τοῖς ἐμοῖς λόγοις.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	οἴμοι, τάχ᾿, ὡς ἔοικας, ὡς νοσεῖς φανεῖς.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	σὺ γάρ μ᾿ ἀπ᾿ εὐνασθέντος ἐκκινεῖς κακοῦ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	δείλαιος, ὡς ἐς πολλὰ τἀπορεῖν ἔχω.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	οὐ γὰρ δικαιοῖς τοῦ φυτεύσαντος κλύειν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1245[/c]ἀλλ᾿ ἐκδιδαχθῶ δῆτα δυσσεβεῖν, πάτερ;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	οὐ δυσσέβεια, τοὐμὸν εἰ τέρψεις κέαρ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	πράσσειν ἄνωγας οὖν με πανδίκως τάδε;
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1241[/sup][/c]φανεῖς Axt: φράσεις codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 246[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Why, when she is the sole cause of my mother’s death, and
	of your being in the state you are, who could make this
	choice, who that has not been made sick by avenging deities?
	It would be better, father, for me too to die than to live
	together with my greatest enemy.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	It seems that this man will not accord me, who am dying,
	what is my due! But a curse from the gods shall await you if
	you disobey my orders!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Alas, you will soon show, it seems, how sick you are!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Yes, for you have stirred me up again after my pain had
	been lulled to sleep.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Unhappy as I am, how many perplexities confront me!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Yes, because you refuse to obey your father!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	But am I then to learn to be disloyal, father?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	It is not disloyalty, if you rejoice my heart!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Then do you order me in all solemnity to do this?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 247[/c]

-021.249 (SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis)
%Sophocles The Women of Trachis
SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἔγωγε· τούτων μάρτυρας καλῶ θεούς.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	τοιγὰρ ποήσω, κοὐκ ἀπώσομαι, τὸ σὸν
	[c dimgray]1250[/c]θεοῖσι δεικνὺς ἔργον. οὐ γὰρ ἄν ποτε
	κακὸς φανείην σοί γε πιστεύσας, πάτερ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	καλῶς τελευτᾷς, κἀπὶ τοῖσδε τὴν χάριν
	ταχεῖαν, ὦ παῖ, πρόσθες, ὡς πρὶν ἐμπεσεῖν
	σπαραγμὸν ἤ τιν᾿ οἶστρον ἐς πυράν με θῇς.
	[c dimgray]1255[/c]ἄγ᾿ ἐγκονεῖτ᾿, αἴρεσθε. παῦλά τοι κακῶν
	αὕτη, τελευτὴ τοῦδε τἀνδρὸς ὑστάτη.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ἀλλ᾿ οὐδὲν εἴργει σοὶ τελειοῦσθαι τάδε,
	ἐπεὶ κελεύεις κἀξαναγκάζεις, πάτερ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΡΑΚΛΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἄγε νυν, πρὶν τήνδ᾿ ἀνακινῆσαι
	[c dimgray]1260[/c]νόσον, ὦ ψυχὴ σκληρά, χάλυβος
	λιθοκόλλητον στόμιον παρέχουσ᾿,
	ἀνάπαυε βοήν, ὡς ἐπίχαρτον
	τελεοῦσ᾿ ἀεκούσιον ἔργον.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΥΛΛΟΣ[/b][/c]

	αἴρετ᾿, ὀπαδοί, μεγάλην μὲν ἐμοὶ
	[c dimgray]1265[/c]τούτων θέμενοι συγγνωμοσύνην,
	μεγάλην δὲ θεῶν ἀγνωμοσύνην
	εἰδότες ἔργων τῶν πρασσομένων,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1259-78[/sup][/c]del. Hartung<li id="note_LCL021_248_1263" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1263[/sup][/c]τελεοῦσ᾿ L. Dindorf: τελέως codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 248[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Women of Trachis[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Yes! I call the gods to witness it!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Then I will do it, and shall not refuse, showing the action to
	the gods as yours! For I could never be shown up as a traitor
	if I obeyed you, father.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	You make a good end, and on top of this swiftly grant me
	this favour, to place me on the pyre before another attack
	comes to tear me or to sting me! Come, make haste, lift me
	up! This is my rest from labour, the final end of this man.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]hyllus[/b][/c]
	Why, there is nothing to prevent these things from being
	accomplished, since you command and you compel me, father.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]Enter hyllus[/c]’ companions, who lift up the stretcher.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Come now, before you stir up again this malady, stubborn
	soul, apply a bit set with stones and let no cry escape me,
	accomplishing this unwelcome task as though it were a
	pleasure!

	Ἀκτὴ μὲν ἥδε τῆς περιρρύτου χθονὸς
	Λήμνου, βροτοῖς ἄστιπτος οὐδ᾿ οἰκουμένη,
	ἔνθ᾿, ὦ κρατίστου πατρὸς Ἑλλήνων τραφεὶς
	Ἀχιλλέως παῖ Νεοπτόλεμε, τὸν Μηλιᾶ
	[c dimgray]5[/c]Ποίαντος υἱὸν ἐξέθηκ᾿ ἐγώ ποτε—ταχθεὶς
	τόδ᾿ ἔρδειν τῶν ἀνασσόντων ὕπο—νόσῳ
	καταστάζοντα διαβόρῳ πόδα·
	ὅτ᾿ οὔτε λοιβῆς ἡμὶν οὔτε θυμάτων
	παρῆν ἑκήλοις προσθιγεῖν, ἀλλ᾿ ἀγρίαις
	[c dimgray]10[/c]κατεῖχ᾿ ἀεὶ πᾶν στρατόπεδον δυσφημίαις,
	βοῶν, ἰύζων. ἀλλὰ ταῦτα μὲν τί δεῖ
	λέγειν; ἀκμὴ γὰρ οὐ μακρῶν ἡμῖν λόγων,
	μὴ καὶ μάθῃ μ᾿ ἥκοντα κἀκχέω τὸ πᾶν
	σόφισμα τῷ νιν αὐτίχ᾿ αἱρήσειν δοκῶ.
	[c dimgray]15[/c]ἀλλ᾿ ἔργον ἤδη σὸν τὰ λοίφ᾿ ὑπηρετεῖν,
	σκοπεῖν θ᾿ ὅπου ᾿στ᾿ ἐνταῦθα δίστομος πέτρα
	τοιάδ᾿, ἵν᾿ ἐν ψύχει μὲν ἡλίου διπλῆ
	πάρεστιν ἐνθάκησις, ἐν θέρει δ᾿ ὕπνον
	δι᾿ ἀμφιτρῆτος αὐλίου πέμπει πνοή.
	[c dimgray]20[/c]βαιὸν δ᾿ ἔνερθεν ἐξ ἀριστερᾶς τάχ᾿ ἂν
	ἴδοις ποτὸν κρηναῖον, εἴπερ ἐστὶ σῶν.

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c]ἰύζων r: στενάζων cett.

	[c dimgray]Page number 256[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	[b]Philoctetes[/b]

	[c dimgray]Scene:[/c] the uninhabited island of Lemnos. Enter odysseus
	and neoptolemus, with a scout.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]odysseus[/b][/c]
	This is the shore of the seagirt land of Lemnos, untrodden
	by mortals, not inhabited. Here it was, you who were
	reared as the son of the noblest father among the Greeks,
	son of Achilles, Neoptolemus, that I once put ashore the
	Malian, the son of Poeas—on the orders of those in
	command—whose foot was dripping from a malady that
	was eating it away; since we could not pour libations or
	sacrifice in peace, but he filled the entire camp with savage
	and ill-omened cries, shouting and screaming. But why
	must I talk of that? It is not the moment for long conversation,
	for fear he should learn that I have come, and I should
	spill out the whole scheme by which I plan at once to take
	him. But from now on your task is to help me, and to see
	where in this place there is a cave with two mouths, such
	that when it is cold there is a double seat in the sun, and in
	summer a breeze wafts sleep through the cavern with its
	opening at both ends. A little below it, on the left, you
	may see a spring with drinking water, if it is still there. Go
	[m1]\ [/m]

-021.263 (SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes)
%Sophocles Philoctetes
SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ[/b][/c]

	τὴν Φιλοκτήτου σε δεῖ
	[c dimgray]55[/c]ψυχὴν ὅπως λόγοισιν ἐκκλέψεις λέγων,
	ὅταν σ᾿ ἐρωτᾷ τίς τε καὶ πόθεν πάρει,
	λέγειν, Ἀχιλλέως παῖς· τόδ᾿ οὐχὶ κλεπτέον·
	πλεῖς δ᾿ ὡς πρὸς οἶκον, ἐκλιπὼν τὸ ναυτικὸν
	στράτευμ᾿ Ἀχαιῶν, ἔχθος ἐχθήρας μέγα,
	[c dimgray]60[/c]οἵ σ᾿ ἐν λιταῖς στείλαντες ἐξ οἴκων μολεῖν,
	μόνην γ᾿ ἔχοντες τήνδ᾿ ἅλωσιν Ἰλίου,
	οὐκ ἠξίωσαν τῶν Ἀχιλλείων ὅπλων
	ἐλθόντι δοῦναι κυρίως αἰτουμένῳ,
	ἀλλ᾿ αὔτ᾿ Ὀδυσσεῖ παρέδοσαν· λέγων ὅσ᾿ ἂν
	[c dimgray]65[/c]θέλῃς καθ᾿ ἡμῶν ἔσχατ᾿ ἐσχάτων κακά.
	τούτῳ γὰρ οὐδέν μ᾿ ἀλγυνεῖς· εἰ δ᾿ ἐργάσῃ
	μὴ ταῦτα, λύπην πᾶσιν Ἀργείοις βαλεῖς.
	εἰ γὰρ τὰ τοῦδε τόξα μὴ ληφθήσεται,
	οὐκ ἔστι πέρσαι σοι τὸ Δαρδάνου πέδον.
	[c dimgray]70[/c]ὡς δ᾿ ἔστ᾿ ἐμοὶ μὲν οὐχί, σοὶ δ᾿ ὁμιλία
	πρὸς τόνδε πιστὴ καὶ βέβαιος, ἔκμαθε.
	σὺ μὲν πέπλευκας οὔτ᾿ ἔνορκος οὐδενὶ
	οὔτ᾿ ἐξ ἀνάγκης οὔτε τοῦ πρώτου στόλου,
	ἐμοὶ δὲ τούτων οὐδέν ἐστ᾿ ἀρνήσιμον.
	[c dimgray]75[/c]ὥστ᾿ εἴ με τόξων ἐγκρατὴς αἰσθήσεται,
	ὄλωλα καὶ σὲ προσδιαφθερῶ ξυνών.
	ἀλλ᾿ αὐτὸ τοῦτο δεῖ σοφισθῆναι, κλοπεὺς
	ὅπως γενήσῃ τῶν ἀνικήτων ὅπλων.
	ἔξοιδα, παῖ, φύσει σε μὴ πεφυκότα
	[c dimgray]80[/c]τοιαῦτα φωνεῖν μηδὲ τεχνᾶσθαι κακά·
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c]λόγοισιν\] δόλοισιν Gedike<li id="note_LCL021_262_61" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]61[/sup][/c]γ᾿ Seyffert: δ᾿ Lr: om. a<li id="note_LCL021_262_66" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]66[/sup][/c]τούτῳ Buttmann: τούτων codd.<li id="note_LCL021_262_79" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]79[/sup][/c]παῖ Erfurdt: καὶ codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 262[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]odysseus[/b][/c]
	You must beguile the mind of Philoctetes by your words.
	When he asks you who you are and what is your family, say
	“the son of Achilles”; that you need not conceal. And you
	are sailing for home, having left the fleet of the Achaeans
	after conceiving a great hatred for them, who after sending
	to implore you to come from home, this being their only
	hope of taking Ilium, when you had come refused to give
	you the arms of Achilles, when you asked for them with full
	rights, but had handed them over to Odysseus. And you
	may add as many of the most extreme insults against me as
	you please, for by that you will give me no pain, but if you
	fail to do it, you will give grief to all the Argives. For if this
	man’s bow is not captured, it is impossible for you to conquer
	the land of Dardanus.Now learn why it is possible for you, but not for me, to
	talk with this man without distrust or danger! When you
	sailed, you had sworn no oath to anyone, you were not
	compelled, and you were not part of the first expedition;
	but I can deny none of these charges. So if he catches sight
	of me while he is master of his bow, I am dead, and I shall
	cause the death of you, my companion, also. This is the
	thing that we must scheme for, for you to steal the invincible
	weapon! I know,my son, that by nature you are not the
	sort of man to speak such words or to plot to harm others.

	he should suddenly fall upon me from somewhere. What is
	his place? Where does he rest? Where is he walking, at
	home or abroad?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	You see here his home, with its two openings, where he reposes
	on the rock.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Yes; where has the sufferer gone away to?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	It is clear to me that it is the need for food that makes him
	trail his painful step somewhere near here. For that is the
	kind of life that he is said to lead, shooting beasts with his
	winged arrows, painfully in his pain, and none, they say,
	draws near him to heal his afflictions.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	I pity him, in that with none among mortals to care for him
	and with no companion he can look on, miserable, always
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	Hail, strangers! Who are you that with the seaman’s oar
	have put in to this land that lacks anchorages and inhabitants?
	Of what country and race would I be right in saying
	you were? The manner of your dress is that of Greece,
	most dear to me. But I would like to hear a voice! Do not
	shrink from me in fear and be repelled at my wild state, but
	take pity on an unhappy man, alone, afflicted like this
	without a companion or a friend, and speak, if indeed you
	have come as friends! But answer me! It is not right that I
	should miss this from you or you from me.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	Why, stranger, first know this, that we are Greeks! That is
	what you wish to learn.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	O dearest of sounds! Ah, what it is to be addressed by such
	a man after so long! What need, my son, made you put in,
	what need brought you here? What was your impulse?
	Which was the dearest of winds? Tell me all this, so that I
	may know who you are!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 279[/c]

	Miserable indeed am I, and hateful to the gods, since no
	news of my plight has made its way home or to any part of
	Greece! But those who threw me out in unholy fashion
	quietly mock me, and my sickness is always flourishing and
	is gaining strength. My son, son whose father was Achilles,
	I am he whom you have heard to be the master of the
	weapons of Heracles, the son of Poeas, Philoctetes, whom
	the two generals and the lord of the Cephallenians
	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c] despicably
	threw out into this desolation, perishing from a cruel
	malady, struck by the cruel sting of the man-slaying serpent.
	In company with that, my son, they left me here
	desolate when they went off, after they had put in here
	from Chryse with their fleet. Gladly then they saw me
	sleeping on the shore in a rocky cavern after much tossing
	from the waves, and went off, leaving me, having put out
	for me, as for a poor wretch, a few rags and a little sustenance
	in the way of food; may they get such themselves!
	What sort of an awakening from sleep do you think was
	mine, my son, when they were gone? What tears do you
	imagine I shed, what sorrows I lamented? I who could see
	that all the ships with which I had sailed were departed,
	and there was no man in the place, no one to support me,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c]Odysseus was king of Ithaca, and the inhabitants of Ithaca
	and other neighbouring islands were often called Cephallenians.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	so much as the commanders; for the whole city and the entire

	[c dimgray][sup]b[/sup][/c] rich in

	the insolence of the sons of Atreus was coming against him,
	when they handed over his father’s weapons—ah, blessed
	one that sits behind bull-slaughtering lions!—an object of
	reverence sublime, to the son of Lartius!

	ἢ πρὸς τὰ Χαλκώδοντος Εὐβοίας σταθμά·
	[c dimgray]490[/c]κἀκεῖθεν οὔ μοι μακρὸς εἰς Οἴτην στόλος
	Τραχινίαν τε δεράδα καὶ τὸν εὔροον
	Σπερχειὸν ἔσται, πατρί μ᾿ ὡς δείξῃς φίλῳ,
	ὃν δὴ παλαιὸν ἐξότου δέδοικ᾿ ἐγὼ
	μή μοι βεβήκῃ. πολλὰ γὰρ τοῖς ἱγμένοις
	[c dimgray]495[/c]ἔστελλον αὐτὸν ἱκεσίους πέμπων λιτάς,
	αὐτόστολον πλεύσαντά μ᾿ ἐκσῶσαι δόμους.
	ἀλλ᾿ ἢ τέθνηκεν, ἢ τὰ τῶν διακόνων,
	ὡς εἰκός, οἶμαι, τοὐμὸν ἐν σμικρῷ μέρος
	ποιούμενοι τὸν οἴκαδ᾿ ἤπειγον στόλον.
	[c dimgray]500[/c]νῦν δ᾿, ἐς σὲ γὰρ πομπόν τε καὐτὸν ἄγγελον
	ἥκω, σὺ σῶσον, σύ μ᾿ ἐλέησον, εἰσορῶν
	ὡς πάντ᾿ ἄδηλα κἀπικινδύνως βροτοῖς
	κεῖται παθεῖν μὲν εὖ, παθεῖν δὲ θἄτερα.
	\[χρὴ δ᾿ ἐκτὸς ὄντα πημάτων τὰ δείν᾿ ὁρᾶν,
	[c dimgray]505[/c]χὤταν τις εὖ ζῇ, τηνικαῦτα τὸν βίον
	σκοπεῖν μάλιστα μὴ διαφθαρεὶς λάθῃ.\]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	last less than one whole day. Bring yourself to do it, take me
	and put me where you will, in the bilge, on the prow, in the
	stern, wherever I am least likely to cause pain to my companions.
	Consent! In the name of Zeus the god of suppliants
	himself, be persuaded! I fall on my knees before you,
	although I am helpless in my misery, lame! But do not
	leave me thus deserted, far from the tread of men, but take
	me either to your home or to the Euboean dwelling of
	Chalcodon—from there I have a short voyage to Oeta and
	the ridge of Trachis and the broad stream of Spercheius—so
	that you can show me to my father. Long since I have
	been afraid that he is gone; for I sent many messages by
	those who came, conveying the entreaties of a suppliant
	that he should sail in person to fetch me home. But either
	he is dead or the messengers, paying small heed to me, as
	was natural, hurried home.But now, since I come to you as one who can bring my
	message and myself, save me, take pity on me, seeing that
	for mortals all things are full of fear and of the danger that
	after good fortune may come evil. \[While free from trouble
	one must look on what is to be feared, and while prosperous,
	then most of all one must look to one’s life in case
	ruin should come upon one unawares.\]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]509[/sup][/c]οἷα Porson: ὅσ(σ)α codd.<li id="note_LCL021_304_517" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]517[/sup][/c]post τὰν add. ἐκ codd., del. Hermann

	Take pity on him, my lord! He has spoken of the ordeal of

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	at me with justice.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]

	ready than you are to work to serve his need. If you are
	agreeable, let us sail, let him set off in haste; the ship will
	carry him and will not refuse! Only may the gods convey us
	safely out of this land to wherever we may desire to sail!

	take yourself away from this land!
	[m1]\ [/m]

	What is he saying, my son? What is this transaction that the
	seaman is carrying on with you in secret?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	I do not yet know what he is saying; but he must say what
	he is going to say openly, to you and me and these men.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]merchant[/b][/c]
	Child of Achilles, do not denounce me to the army for

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]669[/sup][/c]μόνῳ Nauck: μόνον codd.<li id="note_LCL021_320_671-73" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]671-73[/sup][/c]Neoptolemo tribuit Doederlein, Philoctetae codd.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	For [c dimgray]you[/c], my son, this and any other privilege in my gift
	shall be granted.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	Well, I desire it, but this is the nature of my desire; if it is
	right for me, I would like it; but if it is not, let it go!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	Your words are innocent, and it is right, my son; you alone
	have given me the power to see the light of the sun, to see
	the land of Oeta, and my aged father, and my friends, and
	when I lay at the feet of my enemies you raised me up beyond
	their reach. Be assured, it shall be granted you to
	handle it, and to return it to the giver, and to boast that because
	of your nobility you alone among mortals have laid
	hands on it; for it was by doing a kindness that I myself acquired
	it.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]

	I will bring you too in; for my sickness requires me to get
	you to stand by me.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c] was bound and

	[c darkmagenta][b]Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	placed upon a deadly revolving wheel by the all-mighty
	son of Kronos. But there is none other among mortals
	whom I have heard of or have looked upon who has met
	with a more hateful destiny than this man, who having
	done nothing to anyone, done no murder, but being a just
	man among just men, was perishing thus undeservedly.
	But at this I wonder, how, how did he listen alone to the
	waves that beat the shore around him, and endure a life so
	full of tears?Where he was alone, having no one walking near him,
	nor any inhabitant, a neighbour in his troubles, beside
	whom he could have lamented the sickness that cruelly
	devoured him, with groans inviting a response; nor any to
	lull to sleep with healing herbs the burning flux oozing
	from the ulcers of his louse-ridden foot, if a spasm should
	come over him, taking something from the nurturing
	earth. And he moved this way or that, crawling, like a child
	without a loving nurse, searching for his need to be supplied,
	[m1]\ [/m]

	when the plague that devoured his mind abated.He never gathered food from the sowing of the sacred
	earth, never the other things that we men who earn our living
	dispose of, except when with the winged arrows from
	his swift-shooting bow he could acquire the food he
	needed. Poor soul, who for ten whole years lacked even the
	pleasure of the wine cup, and would ever look to find a
	stagnant pool and make his way to it!But now he has met the son of noble men, and will
	attain happiness and greatness through them; and he is
	bringing him in a ship travelling over the sea, after many
	months, to the haunts of the nymphs of Malis, native to
	him, and to the banks of Spercheius, where the man with
	the brazen shield
	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c] joined the gods as a god, blazing with
	fire divine, beyond the hills of Oeta.

	Ah, unlucky one! Unlucky you are found to be in every

	hold you?

	No, not that! But take my bow here, as you asked me for it
	earlier, and guard it and keep it, until the pain of the sickness
	that is now upon me shall abate; for sleep takes me,
	whenever this trouble is departing, and it cannot stop till
	then. You must leave me to sleep peacefully; and if
	meanwhile those people come, I beg you not to let them
	have it, willingly or unwillingly or in any way, in case you
	cause the death both of yourself and me, who am your suppliant.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	should bring trouble upon you, as things were with me and
	with him who had it before me.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]

	and rapid to wherever the god thinks right and our
	mission lies!

	your fathers, do not take away my life! Alas for me! But he
	does not even speak to me any longer, but looks away like
	this, as though he will never let it go.O harbours, O promontories, O society of mountain
	beasts, O jagged rocks, to you, for I know no other I can
	speak to, to my accustomed companions I address my
	lament at the things the son of Achilles has done to me!
	Having sworn to take me home, he is taking me to Troy;
	and having given his right hand as pledge, he has taken and
	is keeping my sacred bow of Heracles the son of Zeus; and
	[m1]\ [/m]

	for me, who knew nothing but that he should obey his orders!
	And you can see now how he is pained by his crime

	its recesses skilfully taught him, inept pupil and unwilling
	as he was, how to be cunning in doing evil. And now, you
	wretch, you mean to tie me up and carry me away from this
	shore, on which you threw me out, friendless, deserted,
	citiless, a corpse among the living! Alas! May you perish!
	Yet I have often prayed for this; but since the gods never
	grant me any pleasure, you are alive and happy, and I feel
	pain at the very thought that I am alive with many troubles,
	mocked by you and by the two generals, sons of Atreus,
	whom you are serving in this matter. Yet you sailed with
	them after being kidnapped and compelled, and I, the unfortunate
	one, had sailed of my own free will with seven

	sail with you, can you make burnt offerings? How can you

-021.393 (SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes)

SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	ἐάν τε νουθετῇ τις εὐνοίᾳ λέγων,
	στυγεῖς, πολέμιον δυσμενῆ θ᾿ ἡγούμενος.
	ὅμως δὲ λέξω· Ζῆνα δ᾿ ὅρκιον καλῶ·
	[c dimgray]1325[/c]καὶ ταῦτ᾿ ἐπίστω, καὶ γράφου φρενῶν ἔσω.
	σὺ γὰρ νοσεῖς τόδ᾿ ἄλγος ἐκ θείας τύχης,
	Χρύσης πελασθεὶς φύλακος, ὃς τὸν ἀκαλυφῆ
	σηκὸν φυλάσσει κρύφιος οἰκουρῶν ὄφις
	καὶ παῦλαν ἴσθι τῆσδε μή ποτ᾿ ἂν τυχεῖν
	[c dimgray]1330[/c]νόσου βαρείας, ἕως ἂν αὑτὸς ἥλιος
	ταύτῃ μὲν αἴρῃ, τῇδε δ᾿ αὖ δύνῃ πάλιν,
	πρὶν ἂν τὰ Τροίας πεδί᾿ ἑκὼν αὐτὸς μόλῃς,
	καὶ τῶν παρ᾿ ἡμῖν ἐντυχὼν Ἀσκληπιδῶν
	νόσου μαλαχθῇς τῆσδε, καὶ τὰ πέργαμα
	[c dimgray]1335[/c]ξὺν τοῖσδε τόξοις ξύν τ᾿ ἐμοὶ πέρσας φανῇς.
	ὡς δ᾿ οἶδα ταῦτα τῇδ᾿ ἔχοντ᾿ ἐγὼ φράσω.
	ἀνὴρ παρ᾿ ἡμῖν ἐστιν ἐκ Τροίας ἁλούς,
	Ἕλενος ἀριστόμαντις, ὃς λέγει σαφῶς
	ὡς δεῖ γενέσθαι ταῦτα· καὶ πρὸς τοῖσδ᾿ ἔτι,
	[c dimgray]1340[/c]ὡς ἔστ᾿ ἀνάγκη τοῦ παρεστῶτος θέρους
	Τροίαν ἁλῶναι πᾶσαν· ἢ δίδωσ᾿ ἑκὼν
	κτείνειν ἑαυτόν, ἢν τάδε ψευσθῇ λέγων.
	ταῦτ᾿ οὖν ἐπεὶ κάτοισθα, συγχώρει θέλων.
	καλὴ γὰρ ἡ ᾿πίκτησις, Ἑλλήνων ἕνα
	[c dimgray]1345[/c]κριθέντ᾿ ἄριστον, τοῦτο μὲν παιωνίας
	ἐς χεῖρας ἐλθεῖν, εἶτα τὴν πολύστονον
	Τροίαν ἑλόντα κλέος ὑπέρτατον λαβεῖν.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1329[/sup][/c]ἂν τυχεῖν Porson: ἐντυχεῖν codd.<li id="note_LCL021_392_1337" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1337[/sup][/c]παρ᾿ Elmsley: γὰρ codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 392[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	and will not accept a counsellor, and if anyone tries to
	teach you, speaking with good will, you turn your back on
	him, thinking him an enemy and an ill-wisher. But all the
	same I will speak, and I call on Zeus the guarantor of oaths!
	Know this, and write it down inside your mind! You
	acquired this painful sickness through an event caused by
	the gods, when you came near to the guardian of Chryse,
	who protects the roofless sanctuary, the snake that keeps
	watch unseen. And know that you will never have respite
	from grievous sickness, so long as the sun rises in one quarter
	and sets again in another, before you come of your own
	will to the land of Troy, and meeting the sons of Asclepius
	that are with us you are relieved of this malady, and with
	this bow and with me you are revealed as the conqueror of
	the towers. I will tell you how I know that this is so! There
	is a man with us who was taken prisoner from Troy,
	Helenus, the noble prophet, who tells us beyond doubt
	that this is bound to happen; and in addition, that it is fated
	that Troy be entirely taken during the present summer;
	and if he is found to be telling lies, he gives us permission
	to kill him. Then since you know this, give your willing
	consent! It is a glorious addition to be reckoned the noblest
	of all the Greeks, and first to come to healing hands,
	and second to take Troy, the cause of so much mourning,
	and win the highest fame!
	[m1]\ [/m]

-021.395 (SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes)

	βλέποντα, κοὐκ ἀφῆκας εἰς Ἅιδου μολεῖν;
	[c dimgray]1350[/c]οἴμοι, τί δράσω πῶς ἀπιστήσω λόγοις
	τοῖς τοῦδ᾿, ὃς εὔνους ὢν ἐμοὶ παρῄνεσεν;
	ἀλλ᾿ εἰκάθω δῆτ᾿; εἶτα πῶς ὁ δύσμορος
	ἐς φῶς τάδ᾿ ἔρξας εἶμι; τῷ προσήγορος;
	πῶς, ὦ τὰ πάντ᾿ ἰδόντες ἀμφ᾿ ἐμοὶκύκλοι,
	[c dimgray]1355[/c]ταῦτ᾿ ἐξανασχήσεσθε, τοῖσιν Ἀτρέως
	ἐμὲ ξυνόντα παισίν, οἵ μ᾿ ἀπώλεσαν;
	πῶς τῷ πανώλει παιδὶ τῷ Λαερτίου;
	οὐ γάρ με τἄλγος τῶν παρελθόντων δάκνει,
	ἀλλ᾿ οἷα χρὴ παθεῖν με πρὸς τούτων ἔτι
	[c dimgray]1360[/c]δοκῶ προλεύσσειν. οἷς γὰρ ἡ γνώμη κακῶν
	μήτηρ γένηται, κἄλλα φιτεύει κακά.
	καὶ σοῦ δ᾿ ἔγωγε θαυμάσας ἔχω τόδε.
	χρῆν γάρ σε μήτ᾿ αὐτόν ποτ᾿ ἐς Τροίαν μολεῖν,
	ἡμᾶς τ᾿ ἀπείργειν οἵδε σου καθύβρισαν,
	[c dimgray]1365[/c]πατρὸς γέρας συλῶντες. εἶτα τοῖσδε σὺ
	εἶ ξυμμαχήσων, κἄμ᾿ ἀναγκάζεις τόδε;
	μὴ δῆτα, τέκνον· ἀλλ᾿ ἅ μοι ξυνώμοσας,
	πέμψον πρὸς οἴκους· καὐτὸς ἐν Σκύρῳ μένων
	ἔα κακῶς αὐτοὺς ἀπόλλυσθαι κακούς.
	[c dimgray]1370[/c]χοὔτω διπλῆν μὲν ἐξ ἐμοῦ κτήσῃ χάριν,
	διπλῆν δὲ πατρός· κοὐ κακοὺς ἐπωφελῶν
	δόξεις ὁμοῖος τοῖς κακοῖς πεφυκέναι.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1361[/sup][/c]κἄλλα Cavallin: τἄλλα codd.: πάντα Reiske φιτεύει L1.-J.: παιδεύει codd.<li id="note_LCL021_394_1364" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1364[/sup][/c]οἵδε Ll.-J.: οἵ τε codd.<li id="note_LCL021_394_1365" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1365[/sup][/c]inter συλῶντες et εἶτα add. οἳ τὸν ἄθλιον | Αἴανθ᾿
	ὅπλων σοῦ πατρὸς ὕστερον δίκῃ | Ὀδυσσέως ἔκριναν codd.,
	del. Brunck
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 394[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	O hateful life, why do you still keep me alive above the
	ground, and have not let me depart to Hades? Alas, what
	am I to do? How am I to disbelieve the words of this man,
	who gave me advice for my own good? But am I to give in?
	Then how can I come into men’s sight, unhappy one, after
	doing this? Who will speak to me? How can you, eyes that
	have witnessed all that has taken place around me, put up
	with this, my being with the sons of Atreus, who were my
	ruin? How can I be with the accursed son of Laertius? It is
	not the pain of the past that stings me, but the sufferings
	still in store for me at their hands that I seem to foresee; for
	when men’s mind has once become the mother of evil
	deeds, it begets yet more evil. And I wonder at this in you;
	for you ought not to go to Troy yourself, and you ought to
	keep me away from it. These men insulted you when they
	robbed you of your father’s treasure; after that will you go
	and fight on their side, and compel me to do the same?
	Never, my son! But as you swore to do, take me home, and
	remain yourself in Skyros and allow these miserable men
	to perish miserably. In this way you will win double gratitude
	from me, and double gratitude from my father; and
	you will not through helping evildoers seem to have a nature
	such as theirs.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 395[/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΦΙΛΟΚΤΗΤΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ὀλεῖς με, γιγνώσκω σε, τοῖσδε τοῖς λόγοις.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΝΕΟΠΤΟΛΕΜΟΣ[/b][/c]

	οὔκουν ἔγωγε φημὶ δ᾿ οὔ σε μανθάνειν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΦΙΛΟΚΤΗΤΗΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1390[/c]ἐγὼ οὐκ Ἀτρείδας ἐκβαλόντας οἶδά με;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΝΕΟΠΤΟΛΕΜΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ἀλλ᾿ ἐκβαλόντες εἰ πάλιν σώσουσ᾿ ὅρα.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΦΙΛΟΚΤΗΤΗΣ[/b][/c]

	οὐδέποθ᾿ ἑκόντα γ᾿ ὥστε τὴν Τροίαν ἰδεῖν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΝΕΟΠΤΟΛΕΜΟΣ[/b][/c]

	τί δῆτ᾿ ἂν ἡμεῖς δρῷμεν, εἰ σέ γ᾿ ἐν λόγοις
	πείσειν δυνησόμεσθα μηδὲν ὧν λέγω;
	[c dimgray]1395[/c]ὥρα ᾿στ᾿ ἐμοὶ μὲν τῶν λόγων λῆξαι, σὲ δὲ
	ζῆν, ὥσπερ ἤδη ζῇς, ἄνευ σωτηρίας.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΦΙΛΟΚΤΗΤΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἔα με πάσχειν ταῦθ᾿ ἅπερ παθεῖν με δεῖ·
	ἃ δ᾿ ᾔνεσάς μοι δεξιᾶς ἐμῆς θιγών,
	πέμπειν πρὸς οἴκους, ταῦτά μοι πρᾶξον, τέκνον,
	[c dimgray]1400[/c]καὶ μὴ βράδυνε μηδ᾿ ἐπιμνησθῇς ἔτι
	Τροίας· ἅλις γάρ μοι τεθρύληται λόγος.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]

Hermann:
	τεθρήνηται cett.  λόγος Ka: λόγοις LVrzt: γόοις γρ in LraT
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	Sir, learn not to be arrogant in your misfortunes!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	You will be my ruin, I know it, with this talk!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	Not I! But I say you do not understand!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	Do I not know it was the sons of Atreus who threw me out?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	Well, see if, having thrown you out, they will not now save
	you!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	Never, if I must of my own will look upon Troy!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	What am I to do, if nothing I can say will persuade you? It is
	time for me to stop talking, and for you to go on living, as
	you are living, without deliverance.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	Allow me to suffer what it is my fate to suffer! But do for
	me what you swore, clasping my right hand, that you would
	do: escort me home! And do not delay or make further
	mention of Troy; for me, enough words have been spoken.
	[m1]\ [/m]

-021.403 (SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes)

	[c dimgray]1420[/c]ἀθάνατον ἀρετὴν ἔσχον, ὡς πάρεσθ᾿ ὁρᾶν.

	[c dimgray]1425[/c]ἀρετῇ τε πρῶτος ἐκκριθεὶς στρατεύματος,

	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	I will prevent them from coming near \[your country\].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	\[But if you do this as you say you will\] Come, when you
	have kissed the ground!

	[c dimgray]
	heracles[/c] appears on the top of the stage building.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Not yet, before you have listened to my words, son of
	Poeas; and say that your ears hear and your eyes view the
	form of Heracles. For your sake I have come, leaving my
	home in heaven, to tell you of the plans of Zeus, and to restrain
	you from the voyage on which you are embarking.
	Do you listen to my words!And first I will tell you of my fortunes, of how many labours
	I endured to go through to win eternal glory, as you
	can see. For you too, know it for sure, destiny is the same,
	after these sufferings to make your life glorious. You shall
	go with this man to the city of Troy and first be cured of
	your grim sickness. And you shall be judged first of the
	army in valour, by means of my bow depriving of life Paris,

-021.405 (SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes)
%Sophocles Philoctetes
SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	τόξοισι τοῖς ἐμοῖσι νοσφιεῖς βίου,
	πέρσεις τε Τροίαν, σκῦλά τ᾿ ἐς μέλαθρα σὰ
	πέμψεις, ἀριστεῖ᾿ ἐκλαβὼν στρατεύματος,
	[c dimgray]1430[/c]Ποίαντι πατρὶ πρὸς πάτρας Οἴτης πλάκα.
	ἃ δ᾿ ἂν λάβῃς σὺ σκῦλα τοῦδε τοῦ στρατοῦ,
	τόξων ἐμῶν μνημεῖα πρὸς πυρὰν ἐμὴν
	κόμιζε. καὶ σοὶ ταὔτ᾿, Ἀχιλλέως τέκνον,
	παρῄνεσ᾿· οὔτε γὰρ σὺ τοῦδ᾿ ἄτερ σθένεις
	[c dimgray]1435[/c]ἑλεῖν τὸ Τροίας πεδίον οὔθ᾿ οὗτος σέθεν·
	ἀλλ᾿ ὡς λέοντε συννόμω φυλάσσετον
	οὗτος σὲ καὶ σὺ τόνδ᾿. ἐγὼ δ᾿ Ἀσκληπιὸν
	παυστῆρα πέμψω σῆς νόσου πρὸς Ἴλιον.
	τὸ δεύτερον γὰρ τοῖς ἐμοῖς αὐτὴν χρεὼν
	[c dimgray]1440[/c]τόξοις ἁλῶναι. τοῦτο δ᾿ ἐννοεῖθ᾿, ὅταν
	πορθῆτε γαῖαν, εὐσεβεῖν τὰ πρὸς θεούς·
	ὡς τἄλλα πάντα δεύτερ᾿ ἡγεῖται πατὴρ
	Ζεύς. οὐ γὰρ ηὑσέβεια συνθνῄσκει βροτοῖς·
	κἂν ζῶσι κἂν θάνωσιν, οὐκ ἀπόλλυται.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΦΙΛΟΚΤΗΤΗΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1445[/c]ὦ φθέγμα ποθεινὸν ἐμοὶ πέμψας,
	χρόνιός τε φανείς,
	οὐκ ἀπιθήσω τοῖς σοῖς μύθοις.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΝΕΟΠΤΟΛΕΜΟΣ[/b][/c]

	κἀγὼ γνώμην ταὐτῇ τίθεμαι.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1440[/sup][/c]ἐννοεῖθ᾿ Elmsley: ἐννοεῖς VTa: ἐννοεῖσθ᾿ cett.<li id="note_LCL021_404_1443" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1443[/sup][/c]οὐ Gataker: ἡ codd.  ηὑσέβεια Dawes: εὐ- codd.<li id="note_LCL021_404_1448" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1448[/sup][/c]γνώμην Lambinus: -ῃ codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 404[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	who was the cause of these troubles, and taking Troy, and
	bringing the spoils to your abode, after receiving the greatest
	prize of the army, for your father Poeas to the topmost
	plain of Oeta, your native place. The spoils you receive
	from this expedition you must bring to my pyre as a memorial
	of my bow. And to you I give the same counsel, son
	of Achilles; for you have not the strength to conquer the
	land of Troy without him, neither has he without you; but
	guard each other like two companion lions! And I will send
	Asclepius to Ilium to put an end to your disease. For it is
	fated to be taken once again by the aid of my bow. But remember
	when you conquer the land to show reverence to
	the gods; for all things come after this in the mind of Zeus
	my father. For reverence for the gods does not die along
	with mortals; whether they live or die, it never perishes.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	O you who have brought to me a voice I longed for, you
	who have appeared at last, I will not disobey your orders!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]neoptolemus[/b][/c]
	I too make the same decision!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 405[/c]

	φέρε νῦν στείχων χώραν καλέσω.
	χαῖρ᾿, ὦ μέλαθρον ξύμφρουρον ἐμοί,

	νῦν δ᾿, ὦ κρῆναι Λύκιόν τε ποτόν,
	λείπομεν ὑμᾶς, λείπομεν ἤδη,
	δόξης οὔ ποτε τῆσδ᾿ ἐπιβάντες.
	χαῖρ᾿, ὦ Λήμνου πέδον ἀμφίαλον,
	[c dimgray]1465[/c]καί μ᾿ εὐπλοίᾳ πέμψον ἀμέμπτως,
	ἔνθ᾿ ἡ μεγάλη Μοῖρα κομίζει,
	γνώμη τε φίλων χὠ πανδαμάτωρ

	χωρῶμεν δὴ πάντες ἀολλεῖς,

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1450-51[/sup][/c]ὅδ᾿ ἐπείγει γὰρ huc traiecit Burges: post πλοῦς
	habent codd.<li id="note_LCL021_406_1455" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1455[/sup][/c]προβολῆς Hermann: προβολὴς Zo: προβλής cett.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 406[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Philoctetes[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]heracles[/b][/c]
	Then do not delay action for long! For the moment for sailing
	is hurrying you on, with the wind at the stern.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]philoctetes[/b][/c]
	Come now, as I depart I will call upon the land! Farewell,
	home that shared my watches, and water nymphs of the
	meadows, and strong sound of sea beating on the promontory,
	where often my head was drenched inside my cave by
	the battering of the wind, and often the mountain of Hermes
	brought back to me a groan answering my voice as the
	storm assailed me! But now, springs and Lycian well, we
	are leaving you, we are leaving now, though we had never
	dared to trust this hope. Farewell, seagirt land of Lemnos,
	and waft me on a peaceful voyage that I cannot complain
	of, to where mighty Fate is taking me, and the will of my
	friends and the all-subduing god who has decreed this!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Let us depart all together, with a prayer to the sea nymphs
	that they may come to bring us safely home.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 407[/c]

-021.413 (SOPHOCLES, Oedipus at Colonus)
SOPHOCLES, Oedipus at Colonus
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	[b]ΟΙΔΙΠΟΥΣ ΕΠΙ ΚΟΛΩΝΩΙ[/b]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΙΔΙΠΟΥΣ[/b][/c]

	Τέκνον τυφλοῦ γέροντος Ἀντιγόνη, τίνας
	χώρους ἀφίγμεθ᾿ ἢ τίνων ἀνδρῶν πόλιν;
	τίς τὸν πλανήτην Οἰδίπουν καθ᾿ ἡμέραν
	τὴν νῦν σπανιστοῖς δέξεται δωρήμασιν,
	[c dimgray]5[/c]σμικρὸν μὲν ἐξαιτοῦντα, τοῦ σμικροῦ δ᾿ ἔτι
	μεῖον φέροντα, καὶ τόδ᾿ ἐξαρκοῦν ἐμοί;
	στέργειν γὰρ αἱ πάθαι με χὠ χρόνος ξυνὼν
	μακρὸς διδάσκει καὶ τὸ γενναῖον τρίτον.
	ἀλλ᾿, ὦ τέκνον, θάκησιν εἴ τινα βλέπεις
	[c dimgray]10[/c]ἢ πρὸς βεβήλοις ἢ πρὸς ἄλσεσιν θεῶν,
	στῆσόν με κἀξίδρυσον, ὡς πυθούμεθα
	ὅπου ποτ᾿ ἐσμέν· μανθάνειν γὰρ ἥκομεν
	ξένοι πρὸς ἀστῶν, ἃν δ᾿ ἀκούσωμεν τελεῖν.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]9[/sup][/c]θάκησιν Zacharias Callierges, coni. Seidler: θάκοισιν cett.<li id="note_LCL021_412_10" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c]prius ἢ πρὸς\] χώροις Hartung<li id="note_LCL021_412_11" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c]πυθοίμεθα: -ώμεθα Brunck
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 412[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	[b]Oedipus at Colonus[/b]

	[c dimgray]The scene is a rural setting, near the sacred grove of the
	Eumenides at Colonus, northwest of Athens. Somewhere
	in the middle of the stage a rock, which can be used as a
	seat, is visible; the grove is bounded by a low ridge of rock,
	and one could sit upon its edge. On the stage can be seen
	the statue of the hero Colonus. Enter oedipus[/c] and
	antigone.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	Child of a blind old man, Antigone, to what regions, or to
	what men’s city have we come? Who on this day shall receive
	Oedipus the wanderer with scanty gifts? I ask for little,
	and I get even less, but for me that is sufficient; for my
	sufferings, and the time that has long been my companion,
	and thirdly my nobility teach me to be content with it. But
	come, my child, if you see any seat, either near ground unconsecrated
	or near the precincts of the gods, stop me and
	let me sit there, so that we may find out where we are; for
	we have come as strangers, and must learn from the citizens
	and do as they tell us.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 413[/c]

-021.415 (SOPHOCLES, Oedipus at Colonus)
%Sophocles Oedipus at Colonus
SOPHOCLES, Oedipus at Colonus
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΑΝΤΙΓΟΝΗ[/b][/c]

	πάτερ ταλαίπωρ᾿ Οἰδίπους, πύργοι μὲν οἳ
	[c dimgray]15[/c]πόλιν στέφουσιν, ὡς ἀπ᾿ ὀμμάτων, πρόσω·
	χῶρος δ᾿ ὅδ᾿ ἱερός, ὡς σάφ᾿ εἰκάσαι, βρύων
	δάφνης, ἐλαίας, ἀμπέλου· πυκνόπτεροι δ᾿
	εἴσω κατ᾿ αὐτὸν εὐστομοῦσ᾿ ἀηδόνες·
	οὗ κῶλα κάμψον τοῦδ᾿ ἐπ᾿ ἀξέστου πέτρου·
	[c dimgray]20[/c]μακρὰν γὰρ ὡς γέροντι προὐστάλης ὁδόν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΙΔΙΠΟΥΣ[/b][/c]

	κάθιζέ νύν με καὶ φύλασσε τὸν τυφλόν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΑΝΤΙΓΟΝΗ[/b][/c]

	χρόνου μὲν οὕνεκ᾿ οὐ μαθεῖν με δεῖ τόδε.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΙΔΙΠΟΥΣ[/b][/c]

	ἔχεις διδάξαι δή μ᾿ ὅποι καθέσταμεν;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΑΝΤΙΓΟΝΗ[/b][/c]

	τὰς γοῦν Ἀθήνας οἶδα, τὸν δὲ χῶρον οὔ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΙΔΙΠΟΥΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]25[/c]πᾶς γάρ τις ηὔδα τοῦτό γ᾿ ἡμὶν ἐμπόρων.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΑΝΤΙΓΟΝΗ[/b][/c]

	ἀλλ᾿ ὅστις ὁ τόπος ἦ μάθω μολοῦσά ποι;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΙΔΙΠΟΥΣ[/b][/c]

	ναί, τέκνον, εἴπερ ἐστί γ᾿ ἐξοικήσιμος.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΑΝΤΙΓΟΝΗ[/b][/c]

	ἀλλ᾿ ἐστὶ μὴν οἰκητός· οἴομαι δὲ δεῖν
	οὐδέν· πέλας γὰρ ἄνδρα τόνδε νῷν ὁρῶ.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]15[/sup][/c]στέφουσιν Wakefield: στέγουσιν codd.<li id="note_LCL021_414_25" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]25[/sup][/c]τοῦτό γ᾿ Aristobulus Apostolides: τοῦτον cett.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 414[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]antigone[/b][/c]
	Unhappy father, Oedipus, the walls that surround the city
	look to be far off; and this place is sacred, one can easily
	guess, with the bay, the olive, and the vine growing everywhere;
	and inside it many feathered nightingales make
	their music. Relax your limbs here on this unhewn rock; for
	you have gone a long way for an aged man.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	Then seat me here and guard me, blind as I am!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]antigone[/b][/c]
	After so long, you do not need to tell me that!
	[c dimgray]She seats oedipus[/c] upon the rock in the middle of the stage.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	Can you explain to me where it is we are?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]antigone[/b][/c]
	I know that it is Athens, but I do not know what place.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	Yes, all the people on the road told us that much.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]antigone[/b][/c]
	But shall I go and discover what place it is?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	Yes, my child, if indeed it can be lived in.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]antigone[/b][/c]
	Why, it is lived in! But I think there is no need to go, for I
	see a man here near us.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 415[/c]

	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]

	ὦ ξεῖν᾿, ἀκούων τῆσδε τῆς ὑπέρ τ᾿ ἐμοῦ
	αὑτῆς θ᾿ ὁρώσης οὕνεχ᾿ ἡμὶν αἴσιος
	[c dimgray]35[/c]σκοπὸς προσήκεις ὧν ἀδηλοῦμεν φράσαι—

	[m1]\ [/m]

	ἄθικτος οὐδ᾿ οἰκητός. αἱ γὰρ ἔμφοβοι

	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΙΔΙΠΟΥΣ[/b][/c]

	τὰς πάνθ᾿ ὁρώσας Εὐμενίδας ὅ γ᾿ ἐνθάδ᾿ ἂν

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]30[/sup][/c]κἀξωρμημένον J. F. Davies: κἀξορμώμενον codd.<li id="note_LCL021_416_35" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]35[/sup][/c]ὧν Elmsley: τῶν codd.<li id="note_LCL021_416_42" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]42[/sup][/c]ἂν Vauvilliers: ὢν codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 416[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	Is he advancing in this direction?
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]Enter peasant[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]antigone[/b][/c]
	No, he is already here! Say whatever the moment calls for,
	since the man is present!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	Stranger, hearing from this girl, who sees for me as well as
	for herself, that you have come to inquire at the right moment
	to resolve our doubts . . .
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Peasant[/b][/c]
	Before you ask me any more questions, leave this seat! The
	ground you occupy cannot be trodden without pollution!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	But what is the place? To which of the gods is it thought to
	belong?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Peasant[/b][/c]
	It is inviolable, and not inhabited; for it belongs to the
	dread goddesses, daughters of Earth and Darkness.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	Who are they to whom I shall pray when I have heard their
	awful name?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Peasant[/b][/c]
	The people here call them the all-seeing Eumenides; but
	different names are right in different places.
	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]

	ξυμφορᾶς ξύνθημ᾿ ἐμῆς.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	ἀλλ᾿ οὐδ᾿ ἐμοί τοι τοὐξανιστάναι πόλεως

	σήμαινε, κοὐκ ἄτιμος ἔκ γ᾿ ἐμοῦ φανῇ.

	τίς ἔσθ᾿ ὁ χῶρος δῆτ᾿ ἐν ᾧ βεβήκαμεν;

Londiniensis a. 1747: τόνδ᾿ codd.<li id="note_LCL021_418_45" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]45[/sup][/c]ὡς Vauvilliers: ὥστ᾿ codd. γε Musgrave: γῆς codd.<li id="note_LCL021_418_47" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]47[/sup][/c]ἐμοί τοι Seidler: ἐμόν τοι LR: μέντοι a

	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	ἔρεισμ᾿ Ἀθηνῶν· οἱ δὲ πλησίοι γύαι
	τόνδ᾿ ἱππότην Κολωνὸν εὔχονται σφίσιν

	Θησεὺς καλεῖται, τοῦ πρὶν Αἰγέως τόκος.

	[c dimgray]70[/c]ἆρ᾿ ἄν τις αὐτῷ πομπὸς ἐξ ὑμῶν μόλοι;

	ὡς πρὸς τί; λέξων ἢ καταρτύσων τί σοι;

	[c dimgray][sup]71[/sup][/c]τί σοι L1.-J.: μόλοι 1zt

	[c dimgray]Page number 420[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	Threshold of this land, the bulwark of Athens; and the
	neighbouring acres boast that their founder is the horseman
	Colonus here,
	[c dimgray][sup]a[/sup][/c] whose name is borne by their community.
	That is the story, stranger; it has no honour in legend,
	but rather in the minds of us who live with it.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	So are there people that live in these places?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Peasant[/b][/c]
	Indeed there are, those that take their name from this god!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	Have they a ruler, or does the people have the say?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Peasant[/b][/c]
	This place is ruled by the king in the city.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]

	gives in return not gratitude, but pain; and do you leave
	this seat and hasten away from my country, for fear you
	may fasten some heavier burden on my city!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]antigone[/b][/c]
	Strangers of respectful mind, since you have not borne
	with my aged father here, having heard of the things he did
	unwittingly, yet pity my unhappy self, I beseech you,
	strangers, when I appeal to you on behalf of my poor
	father. I appeal to you, looking upon your eyes with eyes
	that are not blind, appearing as though I came from your
	own blood, that the miserable man may meet with respect!
	We are in your hands, as though you were a god. Come,
	grant the unhoped-for favour, I beseech you by whatever
	you hold dear, be it a child or a wife or a possession or a
	god! For however hard you look, you will not discern a
	mortal who, when a god drives him, can escape!
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]260[/c]εἰ τάς γ᾿ Ἀθήνας φασὶ θεοσεβεστάτας
	εἶναι, μόνας δὲ τὸν κακούμενον ξένον
	σῴζειν οἵας τε καὶ μόνας ἀρκεῖν ἔχειν;
	κἄμοιγε ποῦ ταῦτ᾿ ἐστίν, οἵτινες βάθρων
	ἐκ τῶνδέ μ᾿ ἐξάραντες εἶτ᾿ ἐλαύνετε,
	[c dimgray]265[/c]ὄνομα μόνον δείσαντες; οὐ γὰρ δὴ τό γε
	σῶμ᾿ οὐδὲ τἄργα τἄμ᾿· ἐπεὶ τά γ᾿ ἔργα με
	πεπονθότ᾿ ἴσθι μᾶλλον ἢ δεδρακότα,
	εἴ σοι τὰ μητρὸς καὶ πατρὸς χρείη λέγειν,
	ὧν οὕνεκ᾿ ἐκφοβῇ με· τοῦτ᾿ ἐγὼ καλῶς
	[c dimgray]270[/c]ἔξοιδα. καίτοι πῶς ἐγὼ κακὸς φύσιν,
	ὅστις παθὼν μὲν ἀντέδρων, ὥστ᾿ εἰ φρονῶν
	ἔπρασσον, οὐδ᾿ ἂν ὧδ᾿ ἐγιγνόμην κακός;
	νῦν δ᾿ οὐδὲν εἰδὼς ἱκόμην ἵν᾿ ἱκόμην,
	ὑφ᾿ ὧν δ᾿ ἔπασχον, εἰδότων ἀπωλλύμην.
	[c dimgray]275[/c]ἀνθ᾿ ὧν ἱκνοῦμαι πρὸς θεῶν ὑμᾶς, ξένοι,
	ὥσπερ με κἀνεστήσαθ᾿ ὧδε σώσατε,
	καὶ μὴ θεοὺς τιμῶντες εἶτα τοὺς θεοὺς
	ποιεῖσθ᾿ ἀμαυροὺς μηδαμῶς· ἡγεῖσθε δὲ
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]260[/sup][/c]γ᾿ Janus Lascaris: τ᾿ codd.<li id="note_LCL021_442_266-67" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]266-67[/sup][/c]με . . . ἴσθι Hertel: μου . . . ἐστὶ codd.<li id="note_LCL021_442_278" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]278[/sup][/c]ποιεῖσθ᾿ ἀμαυροὺς Fraenkel: μώρους ποιεῖσθε KR:
	μωροὺς π. Q: μοίραις π. La
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 442[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Why, know, child of oedipus, that we pity you and him
	equally for your fortune; but for fear of what may come
	from the gods we could not find the strength to say more
	than has now been said to you.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	What help comes from fame, or from a fine reputation that
	flows away in vain, seeing that Athens, they say, has most
	reverence for the gods, and alone can protect the afflicted
	stranger, and alone can give him aid? How is this the case
	with me, when you have made me rise up from these
	ledges and are driving me away, simply from fear of my
	name? For it is not my person or my actions that you fear;
	why, know that my actions consisted in suffering rather
	than in doing, if I must speak of the matter of my mother
	and my father, on account of which you are afraid of me!
	This I know for sure! Yet in my nature how am I evil, I who
	struck back when I had been struck, so that if I had acted
	knowingly, not even then would I have been evil? But as it
	is I got to where I came to in all ignorance; but those who
	have ill used me knowingly destroyed me.Because of this I implore you by the gods, strangers;
	just as you raised me up, even so preserve me, and in no
	wise honour the gods, but then consign them to darkness!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 443[/c]

	ἐκεῖ γὰρ οἱ μὲν ἄρσενες κατὰ στέγας
	[c dimgray]340[/c]θακοῦσιν ἱστουργοῦντες, αἱ δὲ σύννομοι
	τἄξω βίου τροφεῖα πορσύνουσ᾿ ἀεί.
	σφῷν δ᾿, ὦ τέκν᾿, οὓς μὲν εἰκὸς ἦν πονεῖν τάδε,
	κατ᾿ οἶκον οἰκουροῦσιν ὥστε παρθένοι,
	σφὼ δ᾿ ἀντ᾿ ἐκείνοιν τἀμὰ δυστήνου κακὰ
	[c dimgray]345[/c]ὑπερπονεῖτον. ἣ μὲν ἐξ ὅτου νέας
	τροφῆς ἔληξε καὶ κατίσχυσεν δέμας,
	ἀεὶ μεθ᾿ ἡμῶν δύσμορος πλανωμένη,
	γερονταγωγεῖ. πολλὰ μὲν κατ᾿ ἀγρίαν
	ὕλην ἄσιτος νηλίπους τ᾿ ἀλωμένη,
	[c dimgray]350[/c]πολλοῖσι δ᾿ ὄμβροις ἡλίου τε καύμασι
	μοχθοῦσα τλήμων δεύτερ᾿ ἡγεῖται τὰ τῆς
	οἴκοι διαίτης, εἰ πατὴρ τροφὴν ἔχοι.
	σὺ δ᾿, ὦ τέκνον, πρόσθεν μὲν ἐξίκου πατρὶ
	μαντεῖ᾿ ἄγουσα πάντα, Καδμείων λάθρᾳ,
	[c dimgray]355[/c]ἃ τοῦδ᾿ ἐχρήσθη σώματος, φύλαξ δέ μοι
	πιστὴ κατέστης, γῆς ὅτ᾿ ἐξηλαυνόμην·
	νῦν δ᾿ αὖ τίν᾿ ἥκεις μῦθον, Ἰσμήνη, πατρὶ
	φέρουσα; τίς σ᾿ ἐξῆρεν οἴκοθεν στόλος;
	ἥκεις γὰρ οὐ κενή γε, τοῦτ᾿ ἐγὼ σαφῶς
	[c dimgray]360[/c]ἔξοιδα· μή που δεῖμ᾿ ἐμοὶ φέρουσά τι;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΙΣΜΗΝΗ[/b][/c]

	ἐγὼ τὰ μὲν παθήμαθ᾿ ἅπαθον, πάτερ,
	ζητοῦσα τὴν σὴν ποῦ κατοικοίης τροφήν,
	παρεῖσ᾿ ἐάσω. δὶς γὰρ οὐχὶ βούλομαι
	πονοῦσά τ᾿ ἀλγεῖν καὶ λέγουσ᾿ αὖθις πάλιν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]342[/sup][/c]σφῷν: νῦν?<li id="note_LCL021_452_355" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]355[/sup][/c]μοι Jebb: μου codd.<li id="note_LCL021_452_360" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]360[/sup][/c]μή που Housman: μὴ οὐχὶ codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 452[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	there the males sit in their houses working at the loom, and
	their consorts provide the necessities of life out of doors.
	And in your case, my children, those who ought to perform
	this labour sit at home and keep the house like maidens,
	and you two in their place bear the burdens of your
	unhappy father’s sorrows. The one has wandered, poor
	creature, with me, ever since she ceased to be cared for as
	a child and attained her strength, guiding an aged man.
	Straying often through the wild jungle without food or
	footwear, and vexed often by the rain and by the scorching
	sun, the unhappy one gives second place to her home comforts,
	if her father can be cared for. And you, my child,
	came earlier, unbeknown to the Cadmeans, bringing to
	your father all the prophecies that had been uttered with
	regard to this person, and you were my faithful guardian
	when I was driven from the land. And now what news have
	you come bringing to your father, Ismene? What mission
	has sent you forth from home? For you have not come
	empty-handed, that much I know for certain; can you be
	bringing me some cause for fear?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ismene[/b][/c]
	The sufferings I endured, father, while I looked for the
	place where you had settled to maintain yourself I shall
	pass over and let go; for I do not wish to endure the double
	pain of suffering them and then going over them once
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 453[/c]

-021.455 (SOPHOCLES, Oedipus at Colonus)
%Sophocles Oedipus at Colonus
SOPHOCLES, Oedipus at Colonus
	[c darkmagenta][b]SOPHOCLES, Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Sophocles[/b][/c]
	[c dimgray]365[/c]ἃ δ᾿ ἀμφὶ τοῖν σοῖν δυσμόροιν παίδοιν κακὰ
	νῦν ἐστι, ταῦτα σημανοῦσ᾿ ἐλήλυθα.
	πρὶν μὲν γὰρ αὐτοῖς ἤρεσεν Κρέοντί τε
	θρόνους ἐᾶσθαι μηδὲ χραίνεσθαι πόλιν,
	λόγῳ σκοποῦσι τὴν πάλαι γένους φθοράν,
	[c dimgray]370[/c]οἵα κατέσχε τὸν σὸν ἄθλιον δόμον·
	νῦν δ ἐκ θεῶν του κἀξ ἀλειτηροῦ φρενὸς
	εἰσῆλθε τοῖν τρὶς ἀθλίοιν ἔρις κακή,
	ἀρχῆς λαβέσθαι καὶ κράτους τυραννικοῦ.
	χὠ μὲν νεάζων καὶ χρόνῳ μείων γεγὼς
	[c dimgray]375[/c]τὸν πρόσθε γεννηθέντα Πολυνείκη θρόνων
	ἀποστερίσκει κἀξελήλακεν πάτρας.
	ὁ δ᾿, ὡς καθ᾿ ἡμᾶς ἐσθ᾿ ὁ πληθύων λόγος,
	τὸ κοῖλον Ἄργος βὰς φυγάς, προσλαμβάνει
	κῆδός τε καινὸν καὶ ξυνασπιστὰς φίλους,
	[c dimgray]380[/c]ὡς αὐτίκ᾿ αὐτὸς ἢ τὸ Καδμείων πέδον
	τιμῇ καθέξων, ἢ πρὸς οὐρανὸν βιβῶν.
	ταῦτ᾿ οὐκ ἀριθμός ἐστιν, ὦ πάτερ, λόγων,
	ἀλλ᾿ ἔργα δεινά· τοὺς δὲ σοὺς ὅπῃ θεοὶ
	πόνους κατοικτιοῦσιν οὐκ ἔχω μαθεῖν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΙΔΙΠΟΥΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]385[/c]ἤδη γὰρ ἔσχες ἐλπίδ᾿ ὡς ἐμοῦ θεοὺς
	ὤραν τιν᾿ ἕξειν, ὥστε σωθῆναί ποτε;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΙΣΜΗΝΗ[/b][/c]

	ἔγωγε τοῖς νῦν, ὦ πάτερ, μαντεύμασιν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΙΔΙΠΟΥΣ[/b][/c]

	ποίοισι τούτοις; τί δὲ τεθέσπισται, τέκνον;
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]367[/sup][/c]ἤρεσεν Bergk: ἦν ἔρις codd.<li id="note_LCL021_454_380" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]380[/sup][/c]αὐτὸς Nauck: Ἄργος codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 454[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Oedipus at Colonus[/b][/c]
	more. But I have come to tell you of the evils that now
	afflict your two unhappy sons. At first they agreed that the
	throne should be left to Creon and pollution of the city
	avoided, considering the nature of the ancient ruin of the
	family that oppressed your miserable house. But now by
	the action of one of the gods and of their own accursed
	minds there has come upon the thrice-unhappy ones an
	evil rivalry to grasp at dominion and at royal power. The
	younger son, inferior in age, is depriving the first-born,
	Polynices, of the throne and has chased him from his country;
	and he, according to the story that prevails, has gone in
	exile to low-lying Argos and has acquired a new marriage
	and friends who will bear arms with him, resolved either to
	occupy the Cadmean earth in honour or to mount up to
	heaven. This is not a mere heap of words, father, but terrible
	actions; and when the gods will take pity on your sorrows
	I cannot discover.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	Have you then attained the hope that the gods would pay
	some heed to me, so that I might some day be saved?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ismene[/b][/c]
	Yes, father, from the latest prophecies.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]oedipus[/b][/c]
	What are these? What have the oracles pronounced, my
	child?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 455[/c]
